animalOfTheDay.name: topi
facts: They have specialized scent glands that help them mark their territory.
Topis are fast antelopes that can reach speeds of up to 50 mph.
They have a unique 'pronking' behavior where they leap stiff-legged when alarmed.
Male topis defend small territories where females come to mate.

calendar.name: tamarin
facts: Tamarin monkeys are among the smallest primates, some weighing less than a pound.
They often give birth to twins, which is unusual for primates.
Tamarins have claw-like nails instead of flat nails like other monkeys.
They communicate through a variety of high-pitched vocalizations.

calendar.name: tarsier
facts: They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees in each direction.
Tarsiers are the only entirely carnivorous primates, eating insects, lizards, and small birds.
Tarsiers have the largest eyes relative to body size of any mammal.
They communicate using ultrasonic frequencies beyond human hearing.

calendar.name: tasmanian devil
facts: Tasmanian devils are carnivorous marsupials native to Tasmania, Australia.
They are known for their ferocious screeches and powerful bite.
They are the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world.
Tasmanian devils are solitary and nocturnal scavengers.

calendar.name: termite
facts: Termites are more closely related to cockroaches than to ants.
Termite queens can live up to 50 years, making them among the longest-living insects.
Some termite mounds can be over 30 feet tall and contain millions of individuals.
They cultivate fungi in their nests as a food source.

calendar.name: tiger shark
facts: They are born with distinctive stripes that fade as they mature.
Tiger sharks are one of the few shark species that can tolerate freshwater.
They have unique, saw-like teeth that can cut through turtle shells.
Tiger sharks are called 'garbage cans of the sea' because they'll eat almost anything.

calendar.name: toad
facts: They secrete toxins from their skin to deter predators, which can be harmful if ingested.
Toads are more terrestrial than frogs and are often found far from water.
Some toads, like the cane toad, have become invasive species in certain regions.
Toads have dry, warty skin, while frogs have smooth, moist skin.

calendar.name: topi
facts: They have specialized scent glands that help them mark their territory.
Male topis defend small territories where females come to mate.
Topis are fast antelopes that can reach speeds of up to 50 mph.
They have a unique 'pronking' behavior where they leap stiff-legged when alarmed.

randomAnimals.name: sea otter
facts: Sea otters have the densest fur of any animal, with up to 1 million hairs per square inch.
Sea otters hold hands while sleeping to prevent drifting apart.
They play a crucial role in maintaining kelp forest ecosystems by controlling sea urchin populations.
They use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish while floating on their backs.

randomAnimals.name: whale
facts: Blue whales are the largest animals ever – tongues weigh as much as elephants.
Humpback whales create bubble nets to trap fish – cooperative hunting.
Bowhead whales live 200+ years – evidenced by antique harpoons in blubber.
Sperm whales dive 7,000 ft for squid; clicks at 230 decibels stun prey.

randomAnimals.name: peacock
facts: The iridescent colors in their feathers are due to microscopic crystal-like structures.
Only male peafowls are called peacocks; females are peahens, and babies are peachicks.
Peacocks display their feathers to attract mates and deter rivals.
Their extravagant tail feathers, or train, can reach up to 6 feet long.
